newsitem.title: JAPAN: TOCOM precious metals rise, palladium surges.
newsitem.headline: TOCOM precious metals rise, palladium surges.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo precious metal futures ended higher on Tuesday, with nearly all palladium futures surging by their 24 yen per gram daily limit.
Gold futures ranged from 11 yen to 17 yen per gram higher. Benchmark June was up 13 yen at 1,226 yen.
Benchmark June palladium rose by its daily limit of 24 yen to close at 612 yen.
"Despite Russia's resumption of platinum group metal (PGM) exports, lower TOCOM prices relative to spot prices forced investors to cover their shorts," one trader said.
Traders said sentiment towards PGMs remained bullish, given a large overhang in TOCOM short positions held by private investors, especially in palladium futures.
Benchmark June platinum ended up 15 yen at 1,438 yen.
"PGM futures will not fall for a while due to strong palladium demand in the U.S. and lingering concern over Russian PGM supplies," one trader said.
Traders also said a fall in Japan's PGM imports for June released by the Finance Ministry on Tuesday, was due to the suspension in Russian exports.
Buying by private investors boosted gold futures.
In the bullion market, spot gold was quoted at $327.60/328.00 per ounce at 0758 GMT, against $328.50/329.30 in New York on Monday.
Investors were tending to hold moderately bullish views on both TOCOM gold and bullion prices.
Private investors bought gold futures based on a perception that the dollar has more scope to rise against the yen, while trade houses bought spot gold in arbitrage dealings.
Benchmark June silver finished up 3.1 yen per 10 grams at 169.6 yen.
